Thus have I heard

Collection of Tibetan Superstitions, Sayings and Dream Intepretations.

Soot

An infant is never or rarely taken out of the house at night, to prevent evil spirits and other malignant beings from causing it sickness and cursing it. As well, they want to protect the child from seeing anything frightening in the dark, things that adults cannot see but they can. If the baby must be taken out, soot from the hearth is put on its nose and chest. This is drawn upward in a dark line, using the third finger.

February 14, 2014this is vajradog  •  Comment

Smiling Baby

If an infant smiles on meeting a person for the first time, it is believed that the person will live long. “You are auspicious, and may you also live long,” an older Tibetan would respond when a baby smiles on meeting him or her. On the other hand, if the baby cries or makes unpleasant facial expressions, the person will have a short life or else encounter difficult days ahead.

February 14, 2014this is vajradog  •  Comment

Go-Don, Exit

Either three days after the child is born or on an auspicious day the child is taken out of the house for a short outing. The ceremony is called go-don (sgo’-don) meaning ‘exit’. After this the child is not taken out again for at least a month. (This practice is completely ignored nowadays!)

February 14, 2014this is vajradog  •  Comment

While giving birth

When a mother gives birth to a child, she should not touch any of the family property or her own hair immediately after delivery. If she does, it is believed that the particular thing will wear our or be lost quickly. Some orthodox people would give the mother a stone or wood to touch.

February 14, 2014this is vajradog  •  Comment

Girl-child

Tibetans generally prefer the first child to be a girl so that when she grows up, she will not only be more helpful for the family, especially for the mother, but also because it is believed that she will ensure her parents’ long life.

February 14, 2014this is vajradog  •  Comment
